message.content:
cs.SI, cs.SOC, cs.CYBER, cs.IR, cs.CL

This paper examines the distribution of junk news on social media platforms, specifically Twitter and Facebook, and analyzes the polarization and partisanship of the audiences consuming this content. Therefore, the most likely sub-categories are cs.SI (Social and Information Networks) and cs.SOC (Social and Behavioral Sciences), as the paper focuses on social media and its impact on society. Additionally, cs.CYBER (Cybersecurity) is a possible sub-category as the paper discusses the spread of fake news and other forms of junk news. cs.IR (Information Retrieval) and cs.CL (Computation and Language) are also possible sub-categories as the paper analyzes the content of the junk news and the language used in these sources.
